Home Services Updated Friday, May 7

Upcoming Topics

üåπ
Entire Month June

National Rose Month

June is National Rose Month. With over 150 different species throughout North America, roses are in peak bloom in June. They are a hardy plant that can be added to any landscape. #NationalRoseMonth

üíê
June 1-7

National Garden Week

National Garden Week takes place the first full week in June every year. Gardens provide fresh fruits and vegetables, beautify neighborhoods and communities and provide social and physical activities throughout the year. #NationalGardenWeek

ü•µ
Entire Month June

Summer heat

With summer ramping up, so do outside temperatures. Between May and June we see a sizeable increase in average temperature in areas that have typical summers. This means the need for potential emergency repairs, filter changes, and finding ways to keep homes cool without breaking the bank.

üóú

Custom-built homes

With real estate prices in many areas going up, some people are considering custom-built homes. For many, the long-term cost savings of buying a new home are more attractive than maintaining an older home.

ü©±

Pool maintenance

With summer coming, it's important to make sure your pool continues to operate successfully. Skimming, brushing, and vacuuming your pool are just a few things to keep track of when considering pool maintenance. Making sure chemical levels stay where they need to be can take a little more time and practice.

üçÇ

Gutter cleaning

Depending on where you live and if there are trees near your home, you need to make sure your gutters are clear of debris. Having clear gutters insures rainwater flows freely and does not get stuck which can cause standing water. This can cause a number of problems including damage to the gutter itself, excess moisture in walls, mold and mildew.

üêù

Pests That Thrive in the Summer

Mosquitoes, Ants, Fleas, Ticks, Termites, Grasshoppers, Flies, and Stinging Insects

üêú

Pest Control in the Kitchen

Spring pests, like ants, love kitchen spaces because of the availability of potential water and food sources. Crumbs, spill residue, and food left out are some of their favorite snacks. Here are a few things to tackle at the beginning of each season to help prevent pests in the kitchen: -Clean out all of your cabinets and pantry. Discard stale or outdated foods and spices. -Thoroughly clean the inside of your cabinets and replace old shelf paper. -Vacuum behind your appliances‚Äîthere‚Äôs probably a good bit of dust back there! -Clear off your counters and give them a good scrub, looking out for any sticky spots or residue in hard-to-reach areas.

üóú

Remodeling Tip

Remodeling a home isn't for the faint of heart. It's recommended to budget a 10% cushion into your project if you're living in the home while remodeling and 30% if you plan to live elsewhere to account for delays or mishaps during construction.

üå±

The gift of lawn care

As we move towards Mother and Father's Day season, here are seven types of people who would love lawn care as a gift: ‚ñ∏ Someone in Need (Someone who is a busy person or isn‚Äôt physically able); ‚ñ∏ The Amateur Landscaper (The person who wants a beautiful yard and enjoys working in it but struggles to bring it all together); ‚ñ∏ Hard-Working (Give the gift of more time to relax and let the professionals handle the work); ‚ñ∏ A Newbie Homeowner (Lawn care services make a great housewarming gift); ‚ñ∏ New Parents (With a new schedule full of new responsibilities, hiring a lawn care service will go a long way to helping them settle in to parenthood. ‚ñ∏ Providing a lawn care service would take a major task off their plate to focus on the new addition); ‚ñ∏ Someone Selling Their Home (Help sell their home with a beautiful lawn while it‚Äôs on the market. Great landscaping and turf go a long way to create curb appeal); ‚ñ∏ The Person Who Has Everything (Most of us have that person in our life who has everything. Give them the gift of a beautiful, stress-free lawn.)

Seasonal

Spring Maintenance

For many, A/C systems will click on for the first time since last summer. Scheduling routine maintenance can prevent pricey fixes down the road. Tasks often include: testing and cleaning the blower fan, checking the level of coolant in the cooling system, and testing the system‚Äôs thermostat and operation.

HVAC Installation

The spring housing market means folks are getting units installed into new builds or upgrading systems in just-purchased older homes.

üåû
Seasonal

Summer Prep

üí¶
Seasonal

Leak Repair

Springtime has the habit of bringing turbulent weather. Many homeowners struggle with leaky pipes and drains. A few signs of leaky pipes: low water pressure, damaged walls or ceilings, a big water bill increase, mold or mildew, or an unexplained odor.

üö∞
Seasonal

New construction plumbing

The spring housing market means an influx of new homes needing plumbing installation or updates/repairs to older plumbing in a newly-purchased home.

üåß
Seasonal

Spring Floods

Springtime showers can mean trouble for those located in flood zones. Flooded homes, basements, garages, etc. can mean a quick call for emergency plumbing services.

Seasonal

Tricky Trees

After a season of winter weather and storms, folks begin to realize problem areas in their own backyard. Trees leaning dangerously close to the house, trees that have fallen over the last few months, or tree that need to be trimmed to keep residents safe are all top mind for new and tenured home owners.

üßπ
Seasonal

Home Staging

Staging a home can drastically improve the rate at which it sells. It's important to keep in mind those carpets that have been walked on for over a decade or the rug under the dining table that doesn't get a deep clean all the time. Carpet cleaning is a great way to remove dust, dirt, build-up, and improve the air quality in a home.

üíß
Seasonal

Curb Appeal

Curb appeal is a big deal when it comes to selling your home. Hiring a company to pressure wash the driveway and sidewalks of a home before it gets put on the market is an easy way to elevate the look and feel without doing any major renovation.

üí®
Seasonal

Unseen Issues in Old Homes

Older homes have their charm, but also can come with unseen issues. Depending on the age of the property, the chimney might be outdated compared to the rest of the home. An expert will know techniques to repair older and newer chimneys.

ü§ù
Seasonal

A Helpful Hand

Some small fixes are often needed before you close on a house. From switching light fixtures to fixing a leaky toilet, a handyman is perfect to call when there are multiple small fixes that need to get done quickly rather than calling multiple contractors.

üè¨
Trending

Wall-To-Wall Cabinetry

Kitchens are seeing more use after the last year, filling with gadgets and tools to help with at-home meals. This year, we're seeing a shift to wall-to-wall cabinetry instead of smaller units of open shelving or cluttered countertops.

üßº
Trending

Clean-Lined Cabinets

While trends overall are leaning away from minimalism, cabinetry is an exception. More and more homes are opting for more modern cabinets in kitchen and bathrooms instead of a more traditional style.

Common Terms & Phrases

Consider educating your followers about these, as needed

June bugs

The term "June bug" can refer to a number of different species of beetles. The name is derived from the fact that they typically emerge towards the beginning of summer. They are harmless to people and animals but because they are attracted to light, they can be a big nuisance at night. Many pest control companies offer services related to June bug control.

Sump pump

A sump pump moves water from the areas surrounding a house's foundation. The main purpose of a sump pump is to pump and send water away from the house, to a place where it can cause less problems ‚Äî usually a city storm drain. Properly working sump pumps are integral for homes in areas that get a lot of rain or are near sources of water.

Common Early Spring Weeds

Dandelions, White or Dutch Clover, Hairy Bittercress

Common Pests in Spring

Termites, Rats, Mossquitos, Ants, and Spiders

Adhesive

Used to bond tile to a surface.

Field tile

The primary tile used to cover a wall or floor.

Spacers

Plastic pieces that are used in installation to evenly space tiles.

Gauge

The term used to describe the diameter of the electrical wire ‚Äì the larger the number, the thinner the wire. Not to be confused with electric meters.

Service Box

Main electrical panel that holds all the fuses and the more modern circuit breakers. The service box distributes electricity evenly through the house.

Hardscape Elements

Walkways, Driveways, Patios, Swimming pools, Sprinkler systems, Fountains, Stone benches, Gates, Flagstone and other rocks, Arbors

Softscape Elements

Grass, Trees, Shrubs, Flowers, Soil, Vegetable gardens
